item.title: dukan-lite-child
item.dc:creator: bobak.shafiei

item.title: How do I take the course?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded:
This is an online course, which means you can access at any time on any of your internet-enabled devices. We’ve put together a "Getting Started" page, including a welcome video and the following guides, which should answer any questions you may have:
  • The Complete Course Guide
  • Tips for Online Success
  • Tips for English Learners
  • Discussion Board Guide
If you still have questions, look through this FAQ page. If you still need help, you can reach us here, or email us directly at course_support@knovva.com.

item.title: What will the classes be like?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: This course will be a little different than classes you’re used to. There is no teacher. Instead, classes will be made up of content to watch, read, explore, listen to, and navigate, as well as some questions to answer along the way.   Each class will take about an hour to complete, and you can progress through them at your own pace. If you need to pause in the middle, that’s okay! Just make sure you finish the class content, as well as the class project, by the relevant deadlines.

item.title: How much outside / background information is required to successfully complete the course?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Apart from being able to understand, read, and write in English, there is nothing specific you’ll need to know before enrolling. We’ll make sure you have all the information you need to get the most out of this course.

item.title: Is there a syllabus, or somewhere I can see everything that each class contains?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: We’ve put together a Course Guide, which should contain everything you need to know about the course. You can find it here.

item.title: Where should I go if I still have questions?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: We’ve tried to anticipate everything you’ll need to know to take this course, but nobody’s perfect. If you can’t find an answer on our website, or are confused, we’re happy to help! You can reach out to us here. Alternately, you can just email us at course_support@knovva.com, and we’ll get back to you as soon as we can.

item.title: How to log in
item.dc:creator: bobak.shafiei
item.content:encoded: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Omnis enim est natura diligens sui. Illud dico, ea, quae dicat, praeclare inter se cohaerere. Sed ad illum redeo. Et quidem saepe quaerimus verbum Latinum par Graeco et quod idem valeat; Quae quidem sapientes sequuntur duce natura tamquam videntes; Quo modo autem philosophus loquitur?

item.title: Test Q 2
item.dc:creator: bobak.shafiei
item.content:encoded: Test answer 2

item.title: If I don’t do well, will I not be allowed to participate?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Your attendance and attention will guarantee your participation, regardless of how “good” your projects are. As long as you take each class, produce a thoughtful project for each class, and comment meaningfully on your peers’ projects, we’d love to have you participate. If you’re taking this course as part of Knovva’s Model G20 program, please note that we will be offering scholarships for a select group of students in the Knovva program, and your participation in this online course will be taken into consideration.

item.title: When are classes released?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: On the Weekly Units page, each class will become available every Friday morning Eastern Time (ET) (Friday evening in China). Here’s what that looks like: Friday, Dec. 15 - Week 0: Welcome!  Friday, Dec. 22 - Week 1: Introduction to Global Thinking Friday, Dec. 29 - Week 2: Global Politics Friday, Jan. 5 - Week 3: Global Economy Friday, Jan. 12 - Week 4: Cultural Differences Friday, Jan. 19 - Week 5: Our Shared Environment Friday, Jan. 26 - Week 6: Going Global We suggest that you put these dates into your calendar, so you can make sure you have time to view everything, think about it, and get your projects done!

item.title: I am having trouble accessing the course
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: First, check that JavaScript and Flash are turned on in your browser. Next, make sure you are running the latest version of your web browser. If you are still having trouble, please reach out to us here, or by emailing us at course_support@knovva.com.

item.title: What web browser should I be using?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Recommended browsers include Chrome, Edge, or Firefox. While you can still try and take the course with Safari, Internet Explorer, or UC Browser, you may encounter some technical issues, and they are not recommended.

item.title: Why am I not seeing the “next” button?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: You need to click and read through all of the links on a class page before the “next” button will appear. If you still do not see the “next” button, you can navigate to the next section using the menu on the side. (This menu may not appear in all browsers.)

item.title: Will there be due dates?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: There will be due dates. Each class will be released on a Friday. Your projects for each class are due by 11:59 pm Eastern Time (ET) on the Wednesday after the class has been released. This gives you about five days to take each class and complete your project. You then have about 36 hours (until Friday noon, ET) to provide thoughtful comments on at least two of your classmates’ projects.

item.title: When does the course end?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: The final class will be released on Friday, January 26. Your project for the final class will be due the following Wednesday, January 31, and your comments on those projects will be due that Friday, February 2. Once you’ve left your final comments, the class is officially over. But unofficially, we hope this class is just the beginning of your global thinking!

item.title: What happens if I miss a week?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Because this is an online course, each class will remain available until the end of the course. You can always go back and access content for each class if you missed it or want to review it. If you miss a project deadline, you should still try to comment on your classmates’ work by the comment due date. The specific consequences of missing a week will depend on your school. Check with them to make sure you’re clear on their expectations. If you’re taking this course as part of Knovva’s Model G20 program, please note that complete participation in this online course is a valuable and important part of your preparation. Some activities at MG20 will be closely related to course content! In addition, we will be offering scholarships for a select group of students in the MG20, and your participation in this online course will be considered. If you know you will need an extension on a specific week, please reach out to us at course_support@knovva.com

item.title: How do I find the project assignments?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: On the final page of every class, there will be three short project descriptions, and a link to more detailed descriptions. You only have to choose one to complete. On the multimedia discussion board (Padlet), where you post your projects, you can find examples of what a good project might look like.

item.title: When are class projects due?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Courses are released every Friday, and the project for each course is due by by 11:59 pm ET on the following Wednesday, (12:59 pm on Thursday in Beijing). For example, Week 2 becomes available on Friday, December 29. The project for Week 2 is due by 11:59 pm ET on Wednesday, January 3. The projects for Weeks 1-5 shouldn’t take more than an hour to complete, but the project for Week 6 (Going Global) will be your final project, and is a little more involved. Make sure you plan enough time to get it done!

item.title: How do I pass? How does grading work?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: If you’re taking this course as a part of a Knovva program, like the Model G20, grading is done on a pass / fail basis. Basically, if you take each class, submit your projects on time, and comment thoughtfully on each other’s work, you’ll pass. *Please keep in mind that we will be offering scholarships for a select group of students in the Knovva program, and your participation in this online course will be taken into consideration.* If you’re taking this course with one of our partner schools (you know who you are), your teacher (or school) will determine how your participation in our course is graded. You should remember to ask them soon! If you’re some rando who somehow stumbled upon our course, congratulations! You get to determine for yourself whether you pass or not. (We think you deserve a pass for taking the initiative.)

item.title: How do I comment on my classmates’ projects?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded:
You are required to thoughtfully comment on at least two of your peers’ projects every week. To comment, select a post to comment on, click in the “add comment” section, and type your response. In order for your comment to be meaningful, you might want to think about one or more of the following:
  • Ask a question about something you found interesting in their post.
  • Make a connection to their post by sharing a similar experience.
  • Share more information - do you know something about this topic?
Comments are due by 12:00 noon ET on the Friday after the project is due (i.e. 36 hours after the project is due). Further guidelines on using the discussion board and commenting can be found here.

item.title: How do I know my project was submitted?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Once you’ve entered your project into the posting box on the discussion board, click anywhere outside your box. When you can see the heart (♡) and “Add Comment,” your project has been submitted!

item.title: How secure is my information on the multimedia discussion board?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: Padlet is a secure third-party tool we use for all discussion board communication. All Padlets used in the course are private and only accessible by people directly approved by Knovva Academy. For more information on Padlet security, click here.

item.title: Will I be able to keep my projects after the course?
item.dc:creator: alex_krasser
item.content:encoded: At the end of the course, you will have the option of receiving a portfolio -- a collection of your work compiled in a single PDF. If you would like to receive a portfolio of your work, please email course_support@knovva.com after the course has finished.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: knovvaLMS
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Social Innovation - Demo Course
item.dc:creator: knovvaLMS
item.content:encoded:
Welcome students!

This week we focus on the basics of social innovation, defining what it is and exploring the stories of some young innovators. The class is comprised of three parts: interactive class, online discussion, and an individual assignment. Please scroll down to complete all three.

1) Interactive Class:

[iframe_loader type='iframe' width='100%' height='600' frameborder='0' scrolling='no' src='/lms/wp-content/uploads/articulate_uploads/Social-Innovation-Class-1-Demo-Zip/story.html']

2) Online Discussion: 

[bbp-single-topic id=42]

3) Individual Assignment:

This week's individual assignment gives you a chance to research a problem you are passionate about. Detailed instructions and a sample of what a completed assignment might look like are available in the embedded class board (Padlet) below.
To make the Padlet "pop out" click the full screen icon at the top right corner = 
If you are using a tablet or mobile phone, please download the Padlet app, and scan this code from the app to access:

item.title: Getting Started
item.dc:creator: knovvaLMS
item.content:encoded:
Welcome Students! We are so excited to begin this learning journey with you. This week, we focus on what to expect in this online course, and on preparing for a successful experience. We will get all the technology sign-ups out of the way, attempt to answer any question you may have, and introduce you to our multimedia discussion board, which you will then use to introduce yourself to your global classmates.
Starting next week, a new weekly unit will be released every Friday morning (ET). Weekly units will focus on different aspects of global connectivity - from politics, to economics, to culture and the environment. Every week you'll complete a short project, and share it with classmates on the discussion board. The final week of the course will focus on what you can do to continue to engage with global issues, and will include a shorter class and a longer project. Watch the video below to find out more!

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: knovvaLMS
item.content:encoded: We are always here to answer questions about the course, and we would love to hear what you think. Email us directly at course_support@knovva.com, or use the form below to reach a student support specialist. We strive to answer your questions as soon as possible, but please take into account time zone differences. Thank you, we look forward to hearing from you!

item.title: Learn to Be Global, No Matter Where You Are
item.dc:creator: knovvaLMS
item.content:encoded:
Since the beginning of human civilization, cultures on Earth have grown increasingly connected. This process rapidly picked up speed in the 21st century, and today -- the world is smaller than ever before. In such connected times, the importance of developing global understanding and cross-cultural communication skills is quickly becoming an essential part of preparing for success in college, career, and lifelong engagement with global issues and opportunities. In this course, you’ll be introduced to global thinking -- a way to understand how our lives and actions interact with the world at large. In what ways are we connected to people from other places and cultures? Why does it matter? What challenges do we face on a global scale, and how can we come together to solve them? This six-week course will examine some possible answers to these questions through a variety of weekly topics:
  • Week One (Released 12/22): Introduction to Global Thinking
  • Week Two (Released 12/29): Global Politics
  • Week Three (Released 1/5): Global Economy
  • Week Four (Released 1/12): Cultural Differences
  • Week Five (Released 1/19): Our Shared Environment
  • Week Six (Released 1/26): Going Global
